ARTICLE_CONTENT:
Friday, 5:47 PM. The email arrives.

"Reminder: Expense reports due by end of day."

I've been ignoring this email for two weeks.

Not because I don't want my money back. Because finding the receipts feels impossible.

The Reimbursement Game

Here's how it goes at my company:

You pay for something with your own money—a client lunch, an Uber to the airport, supplies for a project. You're supposed to save the receipt, log it in the expense system, and submit for reimbursement.

Simple in theory.

In reality: the receipt goes in your pocket, then your wallet, then a pile on your desk, then... somewhere. The expense system requires seventeen fields and a photo upload that never seems to work on mobile. And by the time the deadline hits, you're reconstructing your spending from bank statements and memory.

Last quarter I left $340 on the table. Expenses I paid for, couldn't prove, didn't get back.

That's my money. Gone. Because of receipts.

The Sunday Night Scramble

You know the scramble.

Expense deadline is Monday. It's Sunday night. You're digging through your camera roll looking for that photo you maybe took of the dinner receipt three weeks ago.

Was it before or after the sunset photo? Scroll. Scroll. Scroll.

There it is—blurry, barely readable, timestamp doesn't match the date you remember.

Now multiply that by fifteen expenses across a month.

This is how I spend my Sundays. Unpaid admin work so I can get paid back for money I already spent.

What Changed

I started texting receipts the moment I get them.

Client dinner? Before I sign the check, I photograph the receipt and text it to TextExpense. Done. Never think about it again.

Uber receipt in my email? Forward it. Done.

Office supplies? Snap it in the parking lot before I drive away.

Each one takes maybe fifteen seconds. No logging into a system. No categorizing. No uploading. Just text and forget.

When the Deadline Hits

Now when the expense report email arrives, I don't panic.

I download my TextExpense report—one Excel file with every receipt from the month, organized by date, with the amounts already extracted.

I copy the data into my company's system. Attach the receipt images. Submit.

Twenty minutes instead of three hours. Everything documented. Nothing missing.

Last month I got reimbursed for 100% of my expenses. First time ever.

The Money You're Leaving Behind

Think about your last few expense reports.

How many receipts did you lose? How many did you just... not submit because finding them felt like too much work?

$50 here. $80 there. A dinner you paid for that you'll never see again.

That's your money. You earned it. You spent it on behalf of your company. You deserve it back.

But no receipt, no reimbursement. That's the rule.
